awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Study of Submesoscale Mixed-Layer Dynamics at a Mid-Latitude Oceanic Front: Isolating the Sub- and Super-Inertial Response to Atmospheric Forcing
awd_abstract_narration:
The ocean mixed-layer is both conduit and barrier for exchange of momentum, heat and gases between the atmosphere and ocean. Recent modeling has revealed a host of competing submesoscale mixed-layer processes which can either promote or inhibit air-sea exchange. These processes are an observational challenge because of the need for unaliased temporal and lateral resolution, as well as sufficient duration to establish persistent mechanisms. This study plans to dramatically improve understanding of 1-10 km scale lateral processes in three-dimensional mixed-layer dynamics with a 28-day experiment in the North Pacific Subtropical Front, a region of above-average atmospheric forcing, typical mid-ocean mesoscale advection and straining, and typical submesoscale activity, maximizing the likelihood of finding significant signals. The results of this observational program will improve the physical basis of mixed-layer parameterizations, leading to better model predictions for air-sea fluxes, gas transfer and biological productivity. The project will train one graduate student and provide research experiences to undergraduate students.  A cruise blog and experiment website will make the results of the project available to the wider scientific community and general public

Multiple ship surveys, profiling float array deployments (16-20 floats measuring temperature, salinity, horizontal velocity and microstructure) and a drifting air-sea flux platform will sample the upper-ocean's response to winter storm forcing in the presence of the mixed-layer fronts that characterize the central ocean gyres. The arrays will profile in sync every 30-40 minutes to eliminate space-time aliasing, cycling between the surface and 100-150 m depth (below the transition layer). During and between deployments, the region will be surveyed repeatedly with (i) a tow-yo body and a shipboard Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler to provide larger-scale context and (ii) a multi-depth flow-through temperature and salinity system to resolve smaller horizontal scales in the upper 2-5 m.  Submesoscale variability in the surface mixed-layer leads to dynamical processes which do not readily satisfy the quasigeostrophic or 1-D surface layer approximations in common use. Although these processes have been examined in isolation or idealized conditions, observational evidence to date is insufficient to clarify whether these subinertial processes are able to operate in the presence of high-frequency atmospheric forcing and strong internal-wave shears. The planned 5-7 array deployments of 3-5 days each will be of sufficient duration to separate the evolution of low-frequency dynamics from near-inertial shear that dominates short timescales, allowing evaluation of mixed-layer restratification and destratification rates by mixed-layer eddies, wind-forcing and vertical processes.

por.por_cntn:
The Sub-mesoscale MIxed-Layer Eddies (SMILE) Experiment carried out an intensive series of experiments in the North Pacific between Hawaii and Oregon in 2017. At three separate sites, differing in latitude, position relative to nearby sea-surface temperature (SST) structures and mesoscale eddies, and distance across the North Pacific Subtropical front, intensive week-long observations were carried out with autonomous profilers, a drifting surface buoy, and a ship-towed profiler. At each site, a cluster of 9-23 EM-APEX (Electro-Magnetic Autonomous Profiling EXplorer) profiling floats measuring temperature, salinity, horizontal velocity, and turbulence were launched from the R/V Sikuliaq in a coherent array, along with the surface buoy. The floats cycled repeatedly to 150 m depth every hour to capture both the spatial structures and temporal variability in the water column. As the float array drifted, the ship made repeated surveys with the SWIMS (Shallow-Water Integrated Mapping System) profiler to measure the spatial context of the drifting measurements. The drifting buoy measured meteorological and oceanic parameters of the air-sea interface, including wind speed and direction, air temperature, ocean temperature, salinity, and currents, and solar radiation to estimate the forcing of the ocean by sun, wind, and air-sea temperature contrast.


The measurements found different upper-ocean behavior at the 3 sites, although a common element to all 3 was a combination of rapidly-varying internal wave motions and slowly-evolving eddy-like motions driven by persistent density contrasts. For the most part, internal waves are able to propagate through the stratified ocean without having a large net effect on the circulation and property transports, but at times the waves can break and lead to vertical mixing. On long timescales, internal waves play a dominant role in the ocean mixing that ultimately determines the extent of the ocean's vertical velocity and stratification (temperature and salinity contrast between the surface and deep layers). By contrast, eddy-like lateral motions are constantly stirring ocean waters horizontally but tend to have little effect on the vertical transport. In the SMILE location of the North Pacific, lateral stirring of temperature and salinity gives rise to a complex vertical structure of alternating cold-fresh and warm-salty layers. Our measurements in the first array (Site 1) were able to track the opposing flows of subsurface intrusions and a light surface layer to explain how the vertical structure of the water column evolved over time. The second array (Site 2) made a full circuit around a counter-clockwise eddy structure, illustrating the processes involved in stirring water into and out of ocean eddies.  The observations of both of these exchange processes were able to illustrate the balance of forces that allow small (1-10 km scale) oceanic structures to evolve in time, providing a test for limited-resolution computer simulations of this process.


The third array (Site 3) was able to observe the springtime restratification process that the experiment was initially designed to target, but which had already occurred prior to March in the first two (more southerly) locations. Over the 5 days following a moderate storm, the 60 m deep mixed layer was capped by warm water, and our float array and ship survey were able to separate the dominant processes involved. The majority of the warming was due to the sun (facilitated by weaker winds) but the spatial nature of our measurements were also able to identify lateral advection of warmer water at a rate which agreed with prior predictions of a Mixed-Layer Eddy (MLE) instability process. Although not the dominant factor influencing upper-ocean stratification, the theory of the MLE process was supported by our measurements, justifying its current inclusion in climate models.


Analysis of the comprehensive SMILE dataset is continuing, and both the eddy exchange process observed at Site 2 and the frontal overturning circulation at Site 1 are candidates for future model parameterization efforts. In addition, spatial structure analysis techniques modified and applied to this dataset have shown promise in being able to separate the energy and dynamics attributable to internal waves and eddies, and this separation will be a valuable tool for future analysis of both ocean observations and numerical model output. Finally, the spatial structures and their evolution as seen in SMILE will provide an important check on the high-resolution sea-surface height fields that will be observed by the upcoming SWOT satellite. Our simultaneous execution of high spatial resolution and continuous rapid sampling allows the inference of the SSH signals on 1-10 km scales that would have been observed with SWOT, and an assessment of how much of this SSH variance is due to internal waves vs. eddies. Although the SMILE measurement program was spatially limited, the global coverage of SWOT will allow our conclusions to be extended to other areas--although additional field experiments will be needed for calibration at different latitudes and different internal wave and eddy environments.
